questions.question_text: A company performs an annual attack surface analysis and identifies a large number of unexpected, external-facing systems. The Chief Information Security Officer wishes to ensure this issue does not reoccur. Which of the following should the company do?

choices.B: Minimize errors in the risk assessment metrics.
choices.D: Reduce the costs associated with performing risk assessments.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
 Continuous monitoring helps identify and address potential risks in real-time, ensuring that any unexpected changes in the attack surface are detected promptly. This proactive approach allows the company to respond quickly to emerging threats and maintain a secure environment.

Selected Answer: D
D. Configure the CA to support OCSP responder services. 
Reason : OCSP (Online Certificate Status Protocol) provides a method for checking the revocation status of certificates in real time. This allows the web applications to verify the validity of certificates quickly without needing to download a full Certificate Revocation List (CRL) every time a request is made. This satisfies both the security requirement (ensuring that certificates are valid and not revoked) and the business requirement (not impacting the web application’s response time significantly).

choices.A: Require each endpoint to validate using a CRL.
choices.B: Implement certificate pinning for all web applications.
choices.C: Outsource PKI management to a managed service provider.
choices.D: Configure the CA to support OCSP responder services.

questions.question_text: An organization wants to set up an internal PKI to support encrypting traffic between internal support web applications and user’s endpoint devices. A security policy requires that certificates must validate for each request to reduce the risk of an on-path attack. The business requires that the solution does not reduce the response of the web applications. Which of the following solutions would best satisfy both the security and business requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Microsegmentation: Microsegmentation is a security technique that divides a network into smaller, isolated segments to limit the movement of potential attackers within the network. It allows for fine-grained control over traffic flows, ensuring that only explicitly allowed traffic is permitted within and between segments. Microsegmentation can filter both intra-VLAN and inter-VLAN traffic, and even traffic between virtual machines (VMs) on the same host, fulfilling the organization’s requirements of restricting traffic based on security policies.

questions.question_text:
A company recently suffered a ransomware outbreak within its virtualized server environment. After the incident, the Chief Information Security Officer created the following requirements for all server environments:

• Only explicitly allowed traffic shall be permitted.
• Inter-VLAN traffic must be filtered.
• Intra-VLAN traffic must be filtered.
• VM traffic residing on the same host must be filtered.

Which of the following best meets these requirements?
Which of the following best describes a risk associated with using facial recognition to locally authenticate to a mobile device?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Biometric impersonation: This involves the risk of someone using a similar face or a high-quality image to trick the facial recognition system into granting access.
